w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach frequency of action words by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: always, usually, sometimes, rarely, never, I usually/sometimes/never/always/rarely ____,
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for frequency of actions
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: always, usually, sometimes, rarely, never
This slide will always be the Naativ-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about the frequency of actions!
Read the frequency words after your teacher
Circle the group of words. Then circle the watch. Explain that these words tell HOW OFTEN we do something.
Circle one picture at a time. Ask the child to name some they should know. Tell the name of the routines the child does not know.
Some we do every day. Some we don’t do every day.
Point to your pretend watch very rapidly
in the white space and have the child repeat.
: Point to your pretend watch very rapidly and have the child repeat.
Circle the calendar. Show that ALWAYS is every day, or a lot.
I always wash my hands after I go to the bathroom.
Circle the picture of the boy washing. Explain that you ALWAYS have to wash your hands after you go to the bathroom.
I always (point to your pretend watch very rapidly) wash my hands after I go to the bathroom.
Point to your pretend watch a little less rapidly
in the white space and have the child repeat.
: Point to your pretend watch a little less rapidly and have the child repeat.
I usually eat cereal for breakfast.
Circle the picture of the boy eating cereal. Circle the cereal box. Explain that you USUALLY eat cereal for breakfast.
I usually (point to your pretend watch a little less rapidly) eat cereal for breakfast.
by reading the sentence from the previous slide again.
Circle the calendar and explain that
means most of the time. Point out that there are only two days that the boy does NOT eat cereal.
Tilt your hand up and down to show a halfway example
in the white space and have the child repeat.
: Tilt your hand up and down to show a halfway example.
Circle the picture of the girl making the bed. Explain that you SOMETIMES make the bed.
I sometimes (tilt your hand up and down) make the bed.
Circle the mini calendar. Show that sometimes is about half of the time.
Draw the frequency words to the box in order of a lot to less
Ask the child, “What is the MOST?” while showing big hands to show the word,
into the first box. Then ask, “Which is next?” Do the action for
by tapping your pretend watch a bit less rapidly. Encourage the child to drag the word
to the second box. Then the child should drag
Read each word. Have the child repeat with correct pronunciation.
Show about an inch with your fingers
in the white space and have the child repeat.
: Show an inch with your fingers.
Circle the picture of the girl taking the bus. Explain that you RARELY take the bus.
I rarely (make and inch with your fingers) take the bus.
Circle the mini calendar. Show that rarely is not much. Maybe one time a week.
in the white space and have the child repeat.
Circle the picture of the boys fighting. Explain that you NEVER fight.
I never (shake your head no) fight.
Circle the calendar. Show that there are zero Xs.
and shake your head. Have the child repeat.
Review the actions for each adverb
and encourage the child to do the action. Repeat with
Say the frequency adverbs with actions.
and do the action. Encourage the child to do the rest.

Draw a line from the picture to the frequency adverb. Say the complete phrase
Model drawing a line from the boys fighting to
